Authors: Harutyunyan V.S., Abrahamyan A.A., Aivazyan A.P.
Title: The elasticity anisotropy in the basal atomic planes of Mg(OH)2 and Ca(OH)2 associated with auxetic elastic properties of the hydrogen sub-lattice
Affiliations: Department of Solid State Physics, Yerevan State University, A. Manukian 1, 375025 Yerevan, Armenia
Authors with affiliations: Harutyunyan, V.S., Department of Solid State Physics, Yerevan State University, A. Manukian 1, 375025 Yerevan, Armenia; Abrahamyan, A.A., Department of Solid State Physics, Yerevan State University, A. Manukian 1, 375025 Yerevan, Armenia; Aivazyan, A.P., Department of Solid State Physics, Yerevan State University, A. Manukian 1, 375025 Yerevan, Armenia
Abstract: Within the framework of the Hook's generalized law and using the experimental data for characteristic crystallographic parameters and stiffness constants available from literature, the individual elastic properties of constituent octahedral layers and interlayers of the (0 0 0 1) atomic planes in the Mg(OH)2 and Ca(OH)2 crystal lattices are theoretically quantified from intermolecular interaction energy. It is shown that, under uniaxial type of deformation applied along the (0 0 0 1) basal planes, in the "load-deformation response" the octahedral layers and interlayers exhibit the positive and negative Poisson's ratio, respectively. Manifestation of such a type strong elastic anisotropy in the basal atomic planes and auxetic elastic behavior of the hydrogen sub-lattice (interlayers) upon applied uniaxial load result from a large difference in the strength of bonding within octahedral layers and interlayers. The intermolecular binding energy is contributed both by "hydroxyl-hydroxyl" and "metal atom-hydroxyl" dispersion interactions, whereas the Young's modulus in the direction parallel to a (0 0 0 1) plane is practically contributed only by the former interaction. For this Young's modulus, an approximate analytical expression is derived, which is convenient for a physical analysis and presumably is also applicable to other metal hydroxides with brucite structure. The proposed theoretical model may be extended to hydrostatic type loading of metal hydroxides for analysis of the hydrogen associated bonding under high-pressure conditions. The approach applied in this study to estimate the dispersive energy may be useful in the evaluation of the physisorption energy for system "H2-metal hydroxide" in terms of the potential application of metal hydroxides as hydrogen storage materials. © 2012 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Anisotropy; High pressure; Hydrogen absorbing materials; Mechanical properties; Rare earth alloys and compounds; Strain

Title: Mechanisms
Abstract: This portion of the Library of Compliant Mechanisms contains Mechanisms, which are defined as systems of rigid bodies connected by elements to achieve a desired motion and/or force transmission. The Mechanism category is subdivided into three subcategories: Kinematic, Kinetic, and Basic. Mechanisms with the primary purpose of obtaining a specified motion, path, orientation, or other positioning relationship, are classified under the Kinematic subcategory. Those mechanisms with the primary purpose associated with their force-defection relationship, energy storage, or other force- or energy-related function, are classified under the Kinetic subcategory. Basic mechanisms are those where the kinematics or kinetics of the mechanism is not defined. This edition first published 2013 © 2013 John Wiley & Sons Ltd.
Author Keywords: Compliant mechanism library; Compliant mechanisms; Kinematic; Kinetic

Authors: Henríquez C., Córdova A., Lutz M., Saavedra J.
Title: Storage stability test of apple peel powder using two packaging materials: High-density polyethylene and metalized films of high barrier
Affiliations: Centro de Investigación y Desarrollo de Alimentos Funcionales (CIDAF), Facultad de Farmacia, Universidad de Valparaíso, Valparaíso, Chile; Escuela de Ingeniería en Alimentos, Pontificia Universidad Católica de Valparaíso, Valparaíso, Chile; Programa de Doctorado en Ciencias de la Ingeniería mención Ingenieria Bioquimica, Pontificia Universidad Católica de Valparaíso, Valparaíso, Chile; Centro de Estudios en Alimentos Saludables (CREAS), Valparaíso, Chile
Authors with affiliations: Henríquez, C., Centro de Investigación y Desarrollo de Alimentos Funcionales (CIDAF), Facultad de Farmacia, Universidad de Valparaíso, Valparaíso, Chile; Córdova, A., Escuela de Ingeniería en Alimentos, Pontificia Universidad Católica de Valparaíso, Valparaíso, Chile, Programa de Doctorado en Ciencias de la Ingeniería mención Ingenieria Bioquimica, Pontificia Universidad Católica de Valparaíso, Valparaíso, Chile; Lutz, M., Centro de Investigación y Desarrollo de Alimentos Funcionales (CIDAF), Facultad de Farmacia, Universidad de Valparaíso, Valparaíso, Chile; Saavedra, J., Escuela de Ingeniería en Alimentos, Pontificia Universidad Católica de Valparaíso, Valparaíso, Chile, Centro de Estudios en Alimentos Saludables (CREAS), Valparaíso, Chile
Abstract: Apples have been identified as one of the main dietary sources of antioxidants, namely phenolic compounds. Apple peel constitutes a waste of dried apple manufacture, although it contains more phenolics than the fruit pulp. This fraction can be preserved by drying. However, it is important to consider that the dehydrated product obtained requires protection. The objective of this research was to study the stability of drum dried apple peel powder in order to select the suitable packing material: high-density polyethylene (HDPE) or metalized films of high barrier (MFHB). The samples were stored under accelerated (38 °C, 90% RH) and conventional (25, 10 and 4 °C, 60-70% RH) conditions during 120 days. Kinetic modelings for the attributes degradation were evaluated. Total phenolics and moisture levels are largely dependent on the type of packing and storage conditions. The apple peel powder samples packed in MFHB pouches preserved most of the phenolic compounds, and exhibited lesser moisture increase. In addition, the shelf-life was higher in the samples packed in MFHB: 298 ± 18.41 days vs. 120 ± 4.59 days under conventional and accelerated conditions, respectively. © 2012 Elsevier B.V.
Author Keywords: Apple; Drum-dried; Packing-material; Phenolics; Storage

Authors: Sabir M.A., Shafiq-Ur-Rehman S., Umar M., Waseem A., Farooq M., Khan A.R.
Title: The impact of suspended sediment load on reservoir siltation and energy production: A case study of the Indus River and its tributaries
Affiliations: Department of Earth Sciences, COMSATS Institute of Information Technology, Abbottabad, Pakistan; Department of Environmental Sciences, University of Peshawar, Pakistan; Department of Chemistry, Quaid-i-Azam University, Islamabad, Pakistan; Department of Chemistry, COMSATS Institute of Information Technology, Abbottabad, Pakistan
Authors with affiliations: Sabir, M.A., Department of Earth Sciences, COMSATS Institute of Information Technology, Abbottabad, Pakistan; Shafiq-Ur-Rehman, S., Department of Environmental Sciences, University of Peshawar, Pakistan; Umar, M., Department of Earth Sciences, COMSATS Institute of Information Technology, Abbottabad, Pakistan; Waseem, A., Department of Chemistry, Quaid-i-Azam University, Islamabad, Pakistan; Farooq, M., Department of Earth Sciences, COMSATS Institute of Information Technology, Abbottabad, Pakistan; Khan, A.R., Department of Chemistry, COMSATS Institute of Information Technology, Abbottabad, Pakistan
Abstract: Suspended sediments load estimation in the Indus River and its important tributaries in Khyber Pakhtunkhwa, Pakistan is presented to determine siltation in major reservoirs in the area and to create a strategy to minimize and/or control this risk for the enhancement of hydel energy production, irrigation, and other domestic purposes. The study area is part of an orogenically active region along the northwestern collision zone of Indian-Eurasian plates. During spring and summer suspended sediment load is highest, but least in winter. Sediment load of all rivers studied is directly proportional to the melting of glaciers and/or high rainfall during spring and summer. Glacier melt, rainfall, lithology of rocks (shale, slate, phyllite, mudstone, and siltstone), discharge, and other anthropogenic factors caused the high suspended load in rivers. Mostly the fine sediments settle during winter due to flow velocity of rivers reducing appreciably and residence time of water increasing in reservoirs. The high sediment influx deposition in major reservoirs like the Terbella and Warsak, etc. reduces their storage capacity as well as power generation capacity. So it is proposed that life span of these reservoirs can be lengthened by the construction of small check dams (silt control dams) on upstream, dam cleaning tactics, effective watershed management, extensive afforestation on the steep mountain slopes upstream of the lake, and the use of runoff rivers for electricity generation using steep gradient and fast flow velocity.
Author Keywords: Environment; Hydel power; Indus River; Siltation in dams; Soft rocks; Suspended load

Authors: Ahmad M., Rafiq M.A., Rasool K., Imran Z., Hasan M.M.
Title: Dielectric and transport properties of bismuth sulfide prepared by solid state reaction method
Affiliations: Micro and Nano Devices Group, Department of Metallurgy and Materials Engineering (DMME), Pakistan Institute of Engineering and Applied Sciences (PIEAS), P.O. Nilore, Islamabad 45650, Pakistan
Authors with affiliations: Ahmad, M., Micro and Nano Devices Group, Department of Metallurgy and Materials Engineering (DMME), Pakistan Institute of Engineering and Applied Sciences (PIEAS), P.O. Nilore, Islamabad 45650, Pakistan; Rafiq, M.A., Micro and Nano Devices Group, Department of Metallurgy and Materials Engineering (DMME), Pakistan Institute of Engineering and Applied Sciences (PIEAS), P.O. Nilore, Islamabad 45650, Pakistan; Rasool, K., Micro and Nano Devices Group, Department of Metallurgy and Materials Engineering (DMME), Pakistan Institute of Engineering and Applied Sciences (PIEAS), P.O. Nilore, Islamabad 45650, Pakistan; Imran, Z., Micro and Nano Devices Group, Department of Metallurgy and Materials Engineering (DMME), Pakistan Institute of Engineering and Applied Sciences (PIEAS), P.O. Nilore, Islamabad 45650, Pakistan; Hasan, M.M., Micro and Nano Devices Group, Department of Metallurgy and Materials Engineering (DMME), Pakistan Institute of Engineering and Applied Sciences (PIEAS), P.O. Nilore, Islamabad 45650, Pakistan
Abstract: We report synthesis of bismuth sulfide (Bi2S3) via conventional solid state reaction method at low temperature ∼150 °C and ambient pressure. X-ray diffraction analysis confirmed the orthorhombic phase of prepared material. Transmission electron microscope images revealed the formation of nanorods having diameter ∼20 nm and length ∼100 nm to ∼150 nm. Impedance and modulus plane plots from 20 Hz to 2 MHz show presence of bulk and grain boundary phases in Bi2S3 at each measurement temperature from 310 K to 400 K. An equivalent circuit model comprised of two resistance-R and constant phase element-Q (RQ) loops in series explains the electrical parameters (resistance and capacitance) and relaxation processes coupled with grains and grain boundaries. The conduction in Bi 2S3 obeyed adiabatic small polaron hopping model. High and temperature dependent dielectric constant was observed in Bi2S 3 suggesting it as an efficient material to be used in capacitive energy storage devices. © 2013 American Institute of Physics.
Index Keywords: Adiabatic small polaron; Ambient pressures; Bismuth sulfide; Capacitive energy storage; Constant phase; Electrical parameter; Equivalent circuit model; Grain boundary phasis; Low temperatures; Measurement temperatures; Orthorhombic phase; Solid state reaction method; Temperature dependent; Transmission electron microscope; Grain boundaries; Nanorods; Solid state reactions; Transmission electron microscopy; Transport properties; X ray diffraction analysis; Bismuth

Title: Transportation: Quick takes: KMEP to expand Houston ship channel storage
Abstract: Kinder Morgan Energy Partners LP is expanding its Houston Ship Channel liquids storage and docking services. The expansion will include the purchase of 42 acres, building a ship dock to handle ocean-going vessels, and building 1.2 million bbl of liquids storage tanks. KMEP entered into a letter of intent with a major ship-channel refiner to develop six 150,000-bbl tanks and four 75,000-bbl tanks with connectivity to its Galena Park terminal and the refiner. The property will provide dock services for as many as 8 vessels/mo for the refinery and 4 vessels/mo for KMEP's terminal. The $170 million expansion will alleviate existing dock congestion among KMEP's HSC terminals and provide additional export capacity. It will also be possible to add a second phase of storage tanks to the project in the future.

statistical inference for a kind of nonlinear regression model; architecture of the monitor system in ternary optical computer; region-based level set model for image segmentation.

Title: Services | Suppliers: Battelle memorial institute
Abstract: The DOE awarded Columbus, OH, multiple awards totaling $6 million to address carbon management and oil field produced waters. Under a program funded by DOE and managed by the National Energy Technology Laboratory (NETL), Battelle will address the growing demand for subsurface brine disposal from oil and gas production in the Northern Appalachian Basin during the next 2 yr. NETL also selected Battelle for two projects dealing with CO2 utilization and storage. Another NETL-funded project is to develop and validate simplified modeling tools for rapid feasibility and risk assessment of CO2 sequestration projects. Battelle has been selected by The World Bank Group to provide consulting services to assist China Power Infrastructure Co explore CO2 storage options from a coal-fired power plant in China's Sichuan Basin.

Title: 2nd International Conference on Materials and Products Manufacturing Technology, ICMPMT 2012
Abstract: The proceedings contain 469 papers. The special focus in this conference is on Composites, Micro/Nano Materials and Technology, Steel, Iron and Technology, Ceramic, Metal Alloy Materials, Polymer Materials and Technology, Physics and Chemistry Materials and Technology, Building Materials, Energy Materials and Fuel Technology, Environmental Friendly Materials and Waste Recycling, Biomaterials, Chemical Materials and Processes, Thin Films, Earthquake Resistant Structures, Materials and Design, Surface Engineering/Coatings, Modeling, Analysis and Simulation, Materials Forming and Processes, Materials Machining, Welding and Joining, Mechanical Behavior and Fracture, Tooling Testing and Evaluation of Materials. Title: 2nd International Conference on Energy, Environment and Sustainable Development, EESD 2012
Abstract: The proceedings contain 334 papers. The special focus in this conference is on Development and Utilization of Solar Energy, Biomass Energy and Wind Energy, Nuclear Energy and Nuclear Engineering, Hydrogen, Fuel Cell and Related Technologies, Heat Pumps Technology, Storage Battery, Energy Storage Technologies, Energy-Saving Technology, Energy Materials and Technology, Energy Chemical Engineering and Processes, Energy Security and Clean Use, New Energy Vehicles and Electric Vehicles, Green Building Materials and Energy-Saving Buildings. The topics include: Benefit assessment of solar photovoltaic industry in China; solar cell MPPT technique based on PI controller; the design of embedded PV inverter grid-connected system; SWOT analysis on Chinese photovoltaic industry; the study on comprehensive utilization of liquefied natural gas; application of bioenergy in Sweden and its revelation to China; hot utilization of fuel gas in fluidized bed biomass gasification; aqueous extraction of Chinese tallow seeds oil; development of straw briquette boiler; the effect of support on the catalytic performance for bio-oil upgrading; steam reforming of biomass tar model compounds over monolithic catalysts; biodiesel production from a novel raw material tung oil; study on the influence of large-scale electric vehicles on power grid; factors affecting future scenarios for alternative vehicles market; energy model of electric vehicle filling station; geotechnical approach to use paper in soil; Authors: Zaman K., Mushtaq Khan M., Ahmad M.
Title: Factors affecting commercial energy consumption in Pakistan: Progress in energy
Affiliations: Department of Management Sciences, COMSATS Institute of Information Technology, Abbottabad, Pakistan; HOD Management Sciences, COMSATS Institute of Information Technology, Abbottabad, Pakistan; HOD Management Sciences, Bahria University, Islamabad, Pakistan
Authors with affiliations: Zaman, K., Department of Management Sciences, COMSATS Institute of Information Technology, Abbottabad, Pakistan; Mushtaq Khan, M., HOD Management Sciences, COMSATS Institute of Information Technology, Abbottabad, Pakistan; Ahmad, M., HOD Management Sciences, Bahria University, Islamabad, Pakistan
Abstract: The purpose of this study is to identify major macroeconomic factors that enhance energy consumption for Pakistan through the cointegration, error correction model and Granger causality tests over a 32-year time period, i.e., between 1980 and 2011. The study employed the bivariate cointegration technique to estimate the long-run relationship between the variables; an error correction model was used to determine the short-run dynamics of the system, while Granger causality test was used to find the directions between these variables. The study investigates the relation between four energy consumption variables (i.e., oil/petroleum consumption, gas consumption, electricity consumption and coal consumption) and four macroeconomic factors which have further sub-classifications, i.e., balance of payment (BOP) factors (i.e., exports, imports, trade deficit, worker's remittances and current account balance), fuel factors (i.e., carbon dioxide emissions, natural resource depletion and net forest depletion), agricultural crops yield per hectare (i.e., wheat, rice, sugarcane, maize and cotton) and industrial production items (i.e., beverages, cigarettes, motor tyres, motor tubes, cycle tyres and cycle tubes) in order to manage robust data analysis. The result confirms the long-run relationship between total commercial energy consumption and macroeconomic factors in Pakistan, as oil/petroleum consumption increases exports, fuel factors, agricultural crops yield per hectare and industrial items; however, the intensity of these factors are different in nature. Carbon dioxide emissions, net forest depletion, beverages, motor tyres and motor tubes are more elastic with oil/petroleum consumption. However, oil/petroleum consumption decreases trade deficit and workers' remittances in Pakistan. Gas, electricity and coal consumption increases agricultural crops yield per hectare and industrial production which shows that as agriculture and industry modernizes, energy demand increases. Energizing the food production chain is an essential feature of agricultural development which is a prime factor in helping to achieve food security in Pakistan. The empirical results only moderately support the conventional view that energy consumption has significant long-run casual effect on macroeconomic variables in Pakistan. The present study finds evident of unidirectional causality between the commercial energy consumption factors and macroeconomic factors in Pakistan. However, there is some bidirectional causality exist which is running between electricity consumption (EC) and exports, EC to imports, EC to carbon emissions, EC to natural resource depletion (NRD) and EC to wheat. The results conclude that macroeconomic variables tend to positively respond to total primary energy consumption. This indicates that increasing total commercial energy consumption may cause growth variables which show that Pakistan is an input-driven economy. © 2012 Elsevier Ltd.
Author Keywords: Coal consumption; Commercial energy consumption; Electricity consumption; Fuel factors; Gas consumption; Oil consumption; Pakistan

The topics include: Investigation of lignite combustion characteristics with thermal analysis; pyrolysis characteristics of oil sands; study on factors influencing pulverized coal ignition time; the combustion analysis of coal under deflagration; Title: Emerging Materials and Processes for Energy Conversion and Storage
Abstract: The proceedings contain 8 papers. The topics discussed include: copper coated LiCoO2 particles for water friendly electrodes in Li-ion batteries; effects of electrode modification on the air electrode for water electrolysis; effects of gas composition just before fuel pulses on power generation characteristics at different fuel supply frequency in pulse jet-rechargeable direct carbon fuel cells; improved effect of anode-additive PrBaInOx and Gd-doped BaCeO3 on the electrochemical performance of solid oxide fuel cells; electrochemical deposition of terbium from molten salts; photochemical route for the preparation of complex amorphous water oxidation catalyst; TiO2 as electron-extraction-layer in reverse type P3HT/ICBA organic solar cells; and continuous fabrication of SOFC assembly by ESD technique - dense thin film YSZ electrolyte.

Title: Kinder Morgan energy partners expands eagle ford shale footprint
Abstract: Kinder Morgan Energy Partners, LP (KMP) has entered into an agreement with a large Eagle Ford Shale producer to extend the Kinder Morgan Crude and Condensate (KMCC) pipeline farther into the Eagle Ford Shale in South Texas. In a $74 million investment, KMP will build an 18-mile, 24-inch lateral pipeline northwest from its DeWitt Station to a new facility in Gonzales County where 300,000 bbl of storage, a pipeline pump station and truck offloading facilities will be constructed. The 300,000-bpd lateral will enable KMP to batch Eagle Ford crude and condensate from the new Gonzales Station via KMCC to its delivery points on the Houston Ship Channel and/or the soon to be completed Sweeny Lateral pipeline serving the Phillips 66 Sweeny Refinery in Brazoria County.

Title: Romania, Hungary at loose ends for gas supply
Abstract: The termination of the Nabucco-West gas pipeline project leaves Romania and Hungary dependent on Russian gas imports. In countries without access to seaborne supplies of LNG, the post-Nabucco default options include building inter-connector pipelines with reverse-flow capability, adding gas storage capacities, and advancing energy market integration on a regional basis, within the EU's evolving energy market. The inter-connector pipeline Hungary-Croatia and the network inter-connection Hungary-Romania are already operational, with 6 and ≤ 5 billion cu m/yr capacities, respectively. The Slovakia-Hungary interconnector (with 5 billion cu m/yr capacity) is due for completion by 2015. However, the gas volumes actually available are nowhere near the capacities of those interconnectors. In Romania, the network interconnection with Hungary is not bi-directional. Romania seeks to prevent even a small-scale outflow of gas cheaply extracted in Romania toward higher-priced European markets.

Title: Meritage scoops up thunder creek gas services
Abstract: Meritage Midstream Services II LLC has acquired 100% ownership of Thunder Creek Gas Services LLC from Devon Energy Corp and PVR Partners LP. Meritage is also developing the Black Thunder Terminal, a joint venture with Arch Coal. Located in Campbell County, WY, at Arch Coal's Black Thunder mining complex, the terminal will provide storage, blending, and rail loading services for crude oil and condensate produced in the basin. Meritage plans to expand the Thunder Creek gathering system to provide pipeline service to the terminal.

Title: Crosstex energy completes phase II expansion at riverside
Abstract: The Crosstex Energy companies completed the Phase II expansion of its Riverside facility on the Mississippi River in southern Louisiana. The Riverside facility's capacity to transload crude oil from railcars to the partnership's barge facility has increased to 15,000 bpd. Phase II additions to the Riverside facility include a 100,000-bbl above-ground crude oil storage tank, a rail spur with a 26-spot crude railcar unloading rack, and a crude offloading facility with pumps, metering, and a truck unloading bay. As part of the Phase II expansion, Riverside was modified so sour crude can be unloaded in addition to sweet crude.

Title: TCE: United Kingdom: Welsh quarry battery will balance energy grid
Abstract: Gwynedd Council in North Wales, UK, has approved a planning permission to Quarry Battery Co (QBC) for a project to build a pumped energy storage system at a disused slate quarry site at Glyn Rhonwy. The 49.9 Mw hydroelectric scheme will provide ≤ 600 Mw-hr of back-up electricity to the grid at times of high demand. QBC's scheme is the most effective way of storing electricity and can replace some fossil fuel stations currently used at times of high demand. Construction will take ∼ 4 yr and use local materials.

Title: Sempra files permit to add facilities at Louisiana LNG terminal
Abstract: Sempra Energy filed a permit application with the FERC, requesting approval to begin construction of natural gas liquefaction and export facilities to its existing Cameron LNG terminal in Hackberry, LA. Construction will start in the fourth quarter of 2013. The liquefaction facility will utilize Cameron LNG's existing facilities, including two marine berths capable of accommodating Q-Flex-sized LNG ships, three LNG storage tanks of 480,000 cu m, and vaporization capability for regasification services of 1.5 bcf/day. The liquefaction facility will comprise three liquefaction trains with a total export capability of 12 million ton/yr of LNG. The facility is expected to begin delivering LNG in 2017.

Title: Lithuania LNG terminal plan delayed
Abstract: Lithuanian state-controlled energy terminal operator Klaipedos Nafta delayed approval of a contractor to build a link to connect its planned LNG terminal to the distribution grid pending a probe of the tender terms. This could hold back launch of the gas platform in late 2014. The disputed tender will build a 20-km pipeline linking the floating LNG terminal to Lithuania's gas distribution network by 10/1/2014. The 2 billion-3 billion cu m/yr regasification and storage facility is planned to go into operation by the end of 2014. The plan would end Lithuania's 100% reliance on imported Russian gas, hinges on unbundling national gas company Lietuvos dujos, which controls sales and the distribution network. The new Lithuanian government has exhibited a far less confrontational approach to Moscow, and plans to talk to Russia about the plan, although it maintains that it will carry it out.

Title: Kinder Morgan wraps up phase one at Bostco
Abstract: Kinder Morgan Energy Partners (KMP) LP announced commercial operations are underway for phase one at the 185-acre Battleground Oil Specialty Terminal Co LLC (BOSTCO) project on the Houston Ship Channel. About 20 of the 51 storage tanks built during phase one were placed in service in October 2013 and the remaining tanks will come online in the next six months. The 7.1-MMbbl BOSTCO terminal is able to handle ultra-low sulfur diesel, residual fuels and other black oil terminal services. Phase two is underway and involves construction of six, 150,000-bbl, ultra-low sulfur diesel tanks, additional pipeline connectivity and high-speed loading at 25,000 bbl/hr. BOSTCO expects phase two to begin service in late 2014.

Title: Companies in the news: ABB has been chosen to supply process analyzers, system integration...
Abstract: ABB has been chosen to supply process analyzers, system integration, and related services for Cheniere Energy's Sabine Pass LNG export facility in Cameron Parish, LA. Located 4 mi from the Gulf Coast in southwestern Louisiana, the new export facility is being built by Bechtel as an expansion of Cheniere's existing Sabine Pass natural gas storage and import terminal. When completed, it will accommodate up to four LNG trains capable of processing ≈ 2 bcf/day of gas liquefaction for transport and potential export. The initial project under construction includes two trains with a liquefaction capacity of 1 bcf/day.

Title: ESI selected by OPA to implement synthesis
Abstract: Energy Solutions International (ESI) was selected by the UK's Oil and Pipelines Agency (OPA) and its operations and maintenance contractor to implement the Synthesis solution across the 1243-mi fuel pipeline and terminal network known as the Government Pipeline and Storage System (GPSS). The Synthesis platform will be implemented to meet the OPA's stock accounting requirements. The OPA is responsible for managing the GPSS for the UK Ministry of Defense.

Title: Western Europe NIBS: Spain: the government ordered a halt...
Abstract: The government ordered a halt to the injection of cushion-gas at the Castor gas storage facility, a depleted oilfield 22 km offshore from Valencia, Spain, after numerous small earthquakes along a stretch of the Mediterranean coast. Studies are being carried out, but Castor's owners (Spain's ACS and Canada's Dundee Energy) have said they will seek compensation if the facility is not allowed to start-up. Castor is designed to hold 1.3 billion cu m of gas.

Title: Lake Charles exports to build LNG liquefaction project
Abstract: The DOE provisionally approved Lake Charles LLC's application to export LNG to countries that do not have free trade agreements with the US. The project calls for the construction of three liquefaction trains with a total capacity of 15 ton/yr LNG, along with the use of existing LNG storage and marine berthing facilities. Pending final investment decisions from Energy Transfer and BG Group, Energy Transfer will complete financing for the potential project and begin construction in middle-2015, with projected in-service date in middle-2019.

Title: Crude oil/frac sand terminal planned in New Mexico
Abstract: Rangeland Energy expects to invest > $150 million in a terminal and supporting infrastructure in Loving, NM. The company has contracts to purchase 770 acres near Loving and plans to begin development of a terminal facility capable of handling crude oil, frac sand, pipe, and other products. A pipeline system is also planned in southern Eddy County, NM, to maximize terminal connectivity to existing and planned pipelines for both the receipt and delivery of crude oil. Rangeland will receive crude produced in southeast New Mexico and West Texas via inbound trucks and gathering pipelines. The terminal will provide crude oil storage and outbound access to existing and planned pipelines. Unit-train loading facilities will allow Rangeland's customers to deliver crude to markets across the country that are not accessible by pipeline.

Title: TCE: Africa: Africa's first underground gas storage planned for Nigeria
Abstract: UNIGAS, a gas transport company and Black Crystal Energy, a resource exploration and development company, are planning for a $2 billion underground gas storage facility in Nigeria - the first of its kind in Africa. The companies are seeking approval from Nigeria's Department of Petroleum Resources to use an abandoned or depleted oil or gas field for the project. The project will provide many benefits for Nigeria, by offering large-scale storage space for exports, improving efficiency in the domestic gas market, providing gas for national power stations, supporting heavy industries including cement, iron and steel, and petrochemicals, and overall, generate more revenue for the country from gas sales.

Title: Transportation: Quick takes: EPP to move diluent from Mont Belvieu to Chicago
Abstract: Enterprise Products Partners LP (EPP) will proceed with development of a project to transport diluent-quality natural gasoline from its Mont Belvieu, TX, liquids storage complex via its 20-in. OD TE Products Pipeline to several potential Chicago-area delivery points. The decision followed an open season during which EPP secured long-term commitments supporting plans to provide access to both Enbridge Inc's Southern Lights and Kinder Morgan Energy Partners LP's Cochin pipelines. EPP expects connections to Southern Lights and Cochin to begin service during the fourth-quarter 2013 and second-quarter 2014, respectively.

Title: Kinder Morgan to expand Sweeny lateral pipeline
Abstract: Kinder Morgan Energy Partners entered into a long-term contract to support the expansion of its Sweeny lateral that it is building from the Kinder Morgan crude condensate pipeline to Phillip 66's refinery in Brazoria County, TX. The expansion will increase capacity on the 27-mi, 12-in. lateral from an initial 30,000 bpd to 100,000 bpd. Kinder Morgan will add new pumps and a 120,000-bbl storage tank at its Wharton pump station in Wharton County, TX, and increase the truck offload capabilities at its DeWitt station in DeWitt County, TX, to handle the higher capacity.

Title: CenterPoint, OGE, ArcLight capital form midstream MLP
Abstract: CenterPoint Energy Inc, OGE Energy Corp, and ArcLight Capital Partners LLC have entered into an agreement to form a master limited partnership that will include CenterPoint Energy's interstate pipelines and field services businesses and the midstream business of Enogex LLC, owned jointly by subsidiaries of OGE and Arclight. The partnership will be managed by a general partner whose governance will be shared by CenterPoint Energy and OGE on a 50:50 basis. The partnership will own and operate 8400 mi of interstate pipelines with ≈ 9 bcf of transport capacity and ≈ 2300 mi of intrastate pipelines. It will also have > 11,000 mi of gathering lines, which in 2012 moved ≈ 4 bcf/day of natural gas. It will also have > 90 bcf of natural gas storage capacity and 11 major processing plants with ≈ 2 bcf/day of inlet capacity.

Title: Double eagle pipeline system completed
Abstract: Double Eagle Pipeline LLC, a joint venture between Magellan Midstream Partners and Kinder Morgan Energy Partners LP, has begun operation of the 85-mi western leg of its pipeline system moving condensate from Gardendale near Cotulla, TX, in LaSalle County to Three Rivers, TX. Operated by Kinder Morgan, the Double Eagle Pipeline includes 140 mi of new 12-in. pipeline connecting to a 50-mi, 14- and 16-in. pipeline segment extending from Three Rivers to Magellan's marine and storage terminal in Corpus Christi. The pipeline has initial capacity of 100,000 bpd but can be expanded to 150,000 bpd with additional pumps.

Title: Asia and Australasia: China: Shell is considering...
Abstract: Shell is considering building a LNG import terminal with Guanghui Energy in eastern China's Jiangsu province. Initially, Guanghui Energy plans to build LNG facilities in Qidong starting with a 600,000 ton/yr storage and transit plant. Under a second phase, the firm aims to build a 1.5 million ton/yr LNG import terminal and a 3.5 million ton/yr import plant in a third stage. All these investments are pending regulatory approvals. Shell would want to jointly invest and operate the facilities from the second phase, and the pair would explore the possibility of setting up a joint venture.

Title: Illinois drives natural gas infrastructure upgrades
Abstract: To leverage abundant natural gas supplies and low wholesale costs, Illinois employer and labor organizations and Ameren Illinois outlined a legislative proposal to accelerate the modernization of Illinois' aging natural gas delivery infrastructure while maintaining Illinois Commerce Commission regulatory oversight. Under the Natural Gas Modernization, Public Safety & Jobs Act, Ameren Illinois will invest $330 million and create 250 jobs to accelerate its ongoing work to strengthen and update its gas transmission, distribution and storage facilities in central and southern Illinois. The 10-yr blueprint will reduce non-hazardous leaks and trim maintenance costs while delivering long-term savings for customers. This is an opportunity for Illinois to develop an important long-term energy infrastructure strategy and plan that creates savings and benefits for our customers while helping grow the economy. The natural gas plan will help lay the foundation for economic development for years to come.

Title: Alliance to buy Kinder Morgan propane terminal
Abstract: Alliance Energy Services will acquire Kinder Morgan Energy Partners LP's (KMP) Benson, MN, propane terminal for $5 million. The terminal supplies > 75 million gal/yr from the Cochin Pipeline System and has a storage capacity of ∼ 1.4 million gal. KMP will quit receiving propane into Cochin next spring prior to the company's Cochin Reversal Project, which involves the modification of the western leg of its pipeline. The move will allow light condensate to move northwest from Kankakee County, IL, to terminal facilities near Fort Saskatchewan, Alberta. Propane deliveries to the terminal are expected to continue until May 2014.

Title: Transportation: Quick takes: Double Eagle pipeline begins condensate shipments
Abstract: Double Eagle Pipeline LLC, a 50:50 joint venture of Magellan Midstream Partners and Kinder Morgan Energy Partners, has started shipping condensate for Eagle Ford shale producers in Karnes and Live Oak counties, TX. Double Eagle line-fill ended, with the system now transporting condensate via KMEP's existing 50-mi, 14-in. and 16-in. OD pipeline from Three Rivers, TX, to Magellan's Corpus Christi, TX, terminal. Double Eagle's new truck unloading and storage facility near Three Rivers also entered service. The joint venture expects to complete construction of Double Eagle's 140-mi, 12-in. OD western leg from Gardendale near Cotulla, TX, in LaSalle County to Three Rivers in the third quarter of 2013. Initial capacity of the pipeline is 100,000 bpd, expandable to 150,000 bpd with additional pumps. Double Eagle was initially proposed by a joint venture consisting of Copano Energy LLC and Magellan. KMEP purchased Copano in early 2013.

Title: Holly energy's crude system expansion in new Mexico
Abstract: Holly Energy Partners (HEP) is proceeding with expansion of its crude oil transportation system in southeastern New Mexico in response to increased crude oil production. The expansion will provide additional pipeline takeaway capacity to either common-carrier pipeline stations for transportation to major crude oil markets or to Holly Frontier's New Mexico refining facilities. HEP will convert an existing refined products pipeline to crude oil service, construct several pipeline segments, expand an existing pipeline, and build truck unloading stations and crude storage capacity. Excluding the value of the existing pipeline to be converted, total expenditures are expected to be $35-$40 million. HEP estimates the project will provide increased capacity of ≤ 100,000 bpd across its system and anticipates it will be in service no later than early 2014.

Title: West Texas gateway and justice NGL pipelines begin service
Abstract: The 570-mi, 16-in. West Texas Gateway NGL Pipeline, which extends from Winkler County in West Texas to ETP's Jackson County processing plant in Jackson County, has been placed in service. Owned by Lone Star NGL LLC, the pipeline transports NGL produced in the Permian and Delaware basins in West Texas to Mont Belvieu, TX, and has an initial capacity of 209,000 bpd with the potential to increase capacity. Energy Transfer Partners LP also placed its 130-mi Justice NGL Pipeline, extending from the Jackson County processing facility to Mont Belvieu, in service. Lone Star has secured capacity on ETP's Justice NGL pipeline for ultimate delivery of NGL to Lone Star's storage and fractionation facilities at Mont Belvieu.

Title: ECS Electrochemical Energy Summit - 222nd ECS Meeting/PRiME 2012: Grand Challenges for Energy Conversion and Large Scale Energy Storage
Abstract: The proceedings contain 1 paper. The topics discussed include: issues and challenges for implementation of large-scale energy storage in Australia.

Title: Intercalation Compounds for Rechargeable Batteries
Abstract: The proceedings contain 20 papers. The topics discussed include: surface control and multi-composite cathodes; bimetallic sulfates A2M(SO 4)2.nH2O (A = Li, Na and M = transition metal): as new attractive electrode materials for Li- and Na-ion batteries; revisiting the lithium iron borate (LiFeBO3) cathode system: synthetic and electrochemical findings; rechargeable batteries: from hybrid materials to devices; novel mesoporous nanotitania/carbon composite electrodes for electrochemical energy storage; improvement of cycle performance of lithium-ion batteries at elevated temperature of 60°C using graphite coated with metal oxide; electrochemical intercalation of bis(trifluoromethanesulfonyl) imide anion into various graphites for dual-ion cells; olivine materials for positive electrodes in Li-ion batteries: electronic properties; and MnO2 nano-rods prepared by redox reaction as cathodes in lithium batteries.

Title: Batteries and Energy Technology (General Session) - 222nd ECS Meeting/PRiME 2012: In Honor of James McBreen
Abstract: The proceedings contain 14 papers. The topics discussed include: an empiric approach to state of charge assessment and range estimation of an electric vehicle; a conjugated sulfide-polymer battery with variable capacitance controlled by redox reaction; comparison of pocket plate and sintered plate Ni electrodes used in energy storage technologies for PV back up applications; graphene as a conductive additive to improve the performance of layered LiNi0.66Co0.17Mn0.17O2 for lithium-ion batteries; polymorphic behavior and morphology of electrospun poly(vinylidene fluoride) separator materials for non-aqueous electrolyte based electric double layer capacitors; direct measurement of vanadium crossover in an operating vanadium redox flow battery; the hydrogen fuel cell vehicles powertrain possible roles in the Kyoto protocol second commitment period perspective in the Pacific rim area; and study of the kinetics of vanadium (II)/(III) redox reaction.

Title: Emerging Materials and Processes for Energy Conversion and Storage
Abstract: The proceedings contain 7 papers. The topics discussed include: synthesis and electrochemical properties of Ni doped spinel LiNixMn2-xO4 (0 ≤ x ≤ 0.5) cathode materials for Li-ion battery; new paradigms for cost-effective III-V photovoltaic technology; electrodeposited CIS and CIGS-based solar cells; one-step electrochemical deposition of Cu-In-Ga mixed oxide thin films for low-cost CIGS solar cells; graphene-quantum dots composite for photovoltaic devices; XRD and Raman spectroscopy study of Fe solubility in cerium oxide; and development of electrically controlled energetic materials (ECEM).

Title: 21st International Materials Research Congress, IMRC 2012
Abstract: The proceedings contain 24 papers. The special focus in this conference is on Composites, Coatings, Electron Microscopy and X-Ray Diffraction. The topics include: Characterization of the thermoelectric behavior of plastically deformed steels by means of relative seebeck coefficient; elimination of Al4C3 phase in Al/SiCP composites by HYSYCVD; spectroscopy study of silver nanoparticles produced by chemical reduction; effects of welding conditions by TIG and post weld heat treatment in ductile cast iron on the corrosion resistance; characterization of the microstructural degradation of platinum modified aluminide coating; analysis of weld bead parameters of overlay deposited on D2 steel components by plasma transferred Arc (PTA) process; high-energy ball-milling of FeAl2 and Fe2Al5 intermetallic systems; structural, textural and thermal characterization of Nano-Mg/Al Hydrotalcite before and after Cr (VI) removal; characterization of Pt-Pd bimetallic nanoparticles by Cs-Corrected STEM; fabrication and characterization of highly ordered porous alumina templates by a two-step anodization process; Ag nanoparticles adsorption on diatom-montmorillonite clays; synthesis of Ag nanoparticles-clinoptilolite composite by homogeneous and heterogeneous nucleation; DSC-TGA hydrogen evaluation during mechanical milling of AlFe intermetallic; microporous carbonaceous materials incorporated with metal (Ti, V and Zn) for hydrogen storage; electrochemical characterization of the structural metals immersed in natural seawater: in situ measures; crystallization and properties of glass-ceramics of the K2O-BaO-B2O3-Al2O3-TiO2 system; structural evolution of FeAl3 intermetallic during high-energy ball-milling; synthesis and thermoluminescent properties of new ZnO phosphors; multilayered zircon-alumina components fabricated by slip casting; electrochemical and tension tests behavior of API 5L X60 pipeline steel in a simulated soil solution; chemical characterization of yellow and orange pollen (helianthus annuus) and its effect in the growth of hydroxyapatite and microstructural behavior during bonding of alumina to niobium by liquid state diffusion.

Title: Chinese Materials Congress 2012, CMC 2012
Abstract: The proceedings contain 149 papers. The special focus in this conference on Advanced Energy Materials and Technology, Thermoelectric Materials, Green Building Materials, Environment Functional Materials, Solar Energy Materials and Technology. The topics include: preparation of polymer capsules for solid hydrogen storage; thermal optimization of exhaust-based thermoelectric generator; preparation and thermoelectric properties of polyaniline doped with protonic acids; a novel thermoelectric generator for the detection of electrical equipment; boundary condition effect on thermoelectric coefficients; thermoelectric properties of Al doped ZnO thin films; preparation and performance testing of foamed concrete; the phase transformation of recycling concrete in recalcination; rapid quantitative identification of thaumasite; optimization chemical composition of the blast furnace slag with uniform design; the application of the steel slag in the radiation shield heavy concrete; the change of silica tetrahedron in cement-silica fume blends hydration; effect of aluminium sulfate on cement properties; experimental study on the pumice aggregate concrete; effect of barium on formation and metastable structure of tricalcium silicate; study on treatment of swine wastewater by sodium type mercerizing zeolite; the removal and inhibitory effect of CNTs on model viruses; study on preparation of hard elastic polypropylene fibers; experimental study of diatomite static adsorption on TP removal in bovine urine wastewater; hypercrosslinked polymers preparation VS methylene blue adsorption; thermodynamic study on the adsorption of nickel ion onto activated carbons; application of the soil infiltration method in the reclaimed water reuse technology; preparation of rubber filler by spent activated carbon; microstructure characterization of Si/C multilayer thin films; ion-beam sputtering deposited cu-doped CdS thin film; the structural characterization and optical properties of zinc oxide films synthesized by electrochemistry method; responses of thin film photovoltaic cell to irradiation under double laser beams of different wavelength.

Title: Chinese Materials Congress 2012, CMC 2012
Abstract: The proceedings contain 149 papers. The special focus in this conference on Advanced Energy Materials and Technology, Thermoelectric Materials, Green Building Materials, Environment Functional Materials, Solar Energy Materials and Technology. The topics include: preparation of polymer capsules for solid hydrogen storage; thermal optimization of exhaust-based thermoelectric generator; preparation and thermoelectric properties of polyaniline doped with protonic acids; a novel thermoelectric generator for the detection of electrical equipment; boundary condition effect on thermoelectric coefficients; thermoelectric properties of Al doped ZnO thin films; preparation and performance testing of foamed concrete; the phase transformation of recycling concrete in recalcination; rapid quantitative identification of thaumasite; optimization chemical composition of the blast furnace slag with uniform design; the application of the steel slag in the radiation shield heavy concrete; the change of silica tetrahedron in cement-silica fume blends hydration; effect of aluminium sulfate on cement properties; experimental study on the pumice aggregate concrete; effect of barium on formation and metastable structure of tricalcium silicate; study on treatment of swine wastewater by sodium type mercerizing zeolite; the removal and inhibitory effect of CNTs on model viruses; study on preparation of hard elastic polypropylene fibers; experimental study of diatomite static adsorption on TP removal in bovine urine wastewater; hypercrosslinked polymers preparation VS methylene blue adsorption; thermodynamic study on the adsorption of nickel ion onto activated carbons; application of the soil infiltration method in the reclaimed water reuse technology; preparation of rubber filler by spent activated carbon; microstructure characterization of Si/C multilayer thin films; ion-beam sputtering deposited cu-doped CdS thin film; the structural characterization and optical properties of zinc oxide films synthesized by electrochemistry method; responses of thin film photovoltaic cell to irradiation under double laser beams of different wavelength.

Title: A comprehensive study of the wind and solar potential of Gau Island, Fiji
Affiliations: School of Applied Sciences, College of Engineering, Science and Technology, Fiji National University, Melanesia, Fiji
Authors with affiliations: Prasad, R.D., School of Applied Sciences, College of Engineering, Science and Technology, Fiji National University, Melanesia, Fiji
Abstract: In Vadravadra village, Gau Island, electricity is provided by a 15 kW diesel generator which is switched on for four hours every evening, and fuel usage is approximately 3,200 L/year. The problem faced by villagers is the constant rise in the price of diesel, which is added to the transportation costs of travelling from the main islands to this remote island, resulting in villagers currently paying approximately FJ$2.80/litre. This paper attempts to determine energy produced (kWh) from wind and solar for electricity generation at the site, as well as the cost of energy (COE). The first section presents the energy supply and demand for the village. The second section gives the wind and solar resource characteristics for the site. The annual average wind speed for the site is 6.2 m/s and the average insolation is 5.50 kWh/m2/day. The third section presents the wind energy potential and size of a stand-alone solar system. Using a 15 kW wind turbine with 0.25 as the overall power coefficient, the estimated annual wind energy yield is 33,700 kWh. With five days storage, the stand-alone solar system requires 84 batteries and 308–125 W PV modules. The next section presents optimum hybrid configuration for the site using HOMER, and finally some conclusions are drawn. © 2013, Springer-Verlag Berlin Heidelberg.
Author Keywords: Battery storage; Cost of energy; Hybrid system; Small wind energy; Solar energy

Title: Design of a piano-keyweir for giritale dam spillway in sri lanka
Source title: Labyrinth and Piano Key Weirs II
Affiliations: Ministry of Irrigation and Water Resources, Colombo, Sri Lanka; Irrigation Department, Colombo, Sri Lanka
Authors with affiliations: Jayatillake, H.M., Ministry of Irrigation and Water Resources, Colombo, Sri Lanka; Perera, K.T.N., Irrigation Department, Colombo, Sri Lanka
Abstract: Giritale Reservoir in Sri Lanka (2 300 hm3), irrigates 3 077 ha in two seasons of the year and its capacity is about 1/2 the seasonal irrigation demand. Working as an on-line reservoir, it is mainly fed by diversions from Mahaweli River System. Since recent, water shortages have been experienced towards end of cropping seasons severely affecting the livelihoods of people settled in the scheme. If the reservoir capacity can be increased, additional diversions from Mahaweli are possible to mitigate the problem. Reservoir is located in a developed area and inundation is a serious limitation when increasing the capacity. With the adoption of PKW, capacity could be increased by 15% without increasing dam height and with minimum inundation. An optimized stepped slope configuration for energy dissipation was incorporated in downstream to minimize tail works. Economy of increasing storage using PKWs against construction of new reservoirs is also presented. © 2014 by Taylor & Francis Group, LLC.

Title: Thermal analysis and design of passive solar buildings
Source title: Thermal Analysis and Design of Passive Solar Buildings
Authors with affiliations: Athieniti, A.K.; Santamouris, M.
Abstract: Passive solar design techniques are becoming increasingly important in building design. This design reference book takes the building engineer or physicist step-by-step through the thermal analysis and design of passive solar buildings. In particular it emphasises two important topics: the maximum utilization of available solar energy and thermal storage, and the sizing of an appropriate auxiliary heating/cooling system in conjunction with good thermal control. Thermal Analysis and Design of Passive Solar Buildings is an important contribution towards the optimization of buildings as systems that act as natural filters between the indoor and outdoor environments, while maximizing the utilization of solar energy. As such it will be an essential source of information to engineers, architects, HVAC engineers and building physicists. © 2002 A K Athienitis and M Santamouris.
Index Keywords: Engineers; Heat storage; Passive solar buildings; Solar energy; Thermoanalysis; Auxiliary heating; Building engineers; Buildings as systems; In-buildings; Outdoor environment; Passive solar design; Thermal control; Thermal storage; Architectural design

Title: Roof cooling techniques: A design handbook
Source title: Roof Cooling Techniques: A Design Handbook
Authors with affiliations: Yannas, S.; Molina, J.L.
Abstract: Natural heating and cooling of buildings helps to improve energy efficiency in the built environment. This book considers the principles of roof design and specific systems and cooling techniques. The authors explain the fundamental principles of roof cooling and describe in detail the relevant components, applications, built precedents, recent experimental work and key design considerations. Specific systems and techniques are examined, including the main advantages and disadvantages of each strategy. Environmental functions are considered in terms of protective strategies and selective strategies. Protective strategies include solar control, thermal insulation, heat storage and thermal inertia. Selective strategies include radiative, evaporative and convective cooling and planting of roofs. Traditional and current roof construction practices are described, exemplified by case studies from across Europe. Including a free CD-ROM with software that enables readers to evaluate their own designs, this book will be invaluable for architects and engineers who wish to create buildings that are more energy-efficient. © Simos Yannas, Evyatar Erell and Jose Luis Molina, 2006. All rights reserved.
Index Keywords: Cooling; Cooling systems; Energy efficiency; Heat storage; Thermal insulation; Convective cooling; Design considerations; Environmental functions; Fundamental principles; Heating and cooling of buildings; Relevant components; Roof constructions; Selective strategies; Roofs

Title: Proceedings: International Conference on Parallel Processing - The 42nd Annual Conference, ICPP 2013
Source title: Proceedings of the International Conference on Parallel Processing
Abstract: The proceedings contain 118 papers. The topics discussed include: parallel birth and death process for cell nuclei extraction in histopathology images; application-aware workload consolidation to minimize both energy consumption and network load in cloud environments; risk intelligence: profitting from uncertainty in data processing system; use of a mobile sink for maximizing data collection in energy harvesting sensor networks; handling uncertainty: Pareto-efficient BoT scheduling on hybrid clouds; efficient forwarding of producer-consumer data in task-based programs; parallelization of particle-in-cell codes for nonlinear kinetic models from mathematical physics; symbolic analysis of concurrency errors in OpenMP programs; Java with auto-parallelization on graphics coprocessing architecture; load-balanced recovery schemes for single-disk failure in storage systems with any erasure code; and a flexible framework to enhance RAID-6 scalability via exploiting the similarities among MDS codes.

Authors: Audelo M., Barahona D., Cadena P., Carrera E., Cazar D., Díaz Castro M., Echeverría M., Orbe J., Recalde C., Suárez R., Tene T., Vásquez N., Zabala L.
Title: Implementing a WCD detector system in Riobamba (Ecuador) as part of the LAGO Project
Source title: Proceedings of the 33rd International Cosmic Rays Conference, ICRC 2013
Affiliations: Escuela Politécnica del Ejército, Quito-, Ecuador; Escuela Politécnica Nacional, Quito-, Ecuador; Escuela Superior Politécnica del Chimborazo, Riobamba-, Ecuador; Universidad Nacional de Chimborazo, Riobamba-, Ecuador; Universidad San Francisco de Quito, Quito-, Ecuador
Authors with affiliations: Audelo, M., Escuela Superior Politécnica del Chimborazo, Riobamba-, Ecuador; Barahona, D., Universidad Nacional de Chimborazo, Riobamba-, Ecuador; Cadena, P., Escuela Superior Politécnica del Chimborazo, Riobamba-, Ecuador; Carrera, E., Universidad San Francisco de Quito, Quito-, Ecuador; Cazar, D., Escuela Superior Politécnica del Chimborazo, Riobamba-, Ecuador; Díaz Castro, M., Escuela Politécnica del Ejército, Quito-, Ecuador; Echeverría, M., Escuela Superior Politécnica del Chimborazo, Riobamba-, Ecuador; Orbe, J., Escuela Superior Politécnica del Chimborazo, Riobamba-, Ecuador; Recalde, C., Escuela Superior Politécnica del Chimborazo, Riobamba-, Ecuador; Suárez, R., Escuela Superior Politécnica del Chimborazo, Riobamba-, Ecuador; Tene, T., Escuela Superior Politécnica del Chimborazo, Riobamba-, Ecuador; Vásquez, N., Escuela Politécnica Nacional, Quito-, Ecuador; Zabala, L., Escuela Superior Politécnica del Chimborazo, Riobamba-, Ecuador
Abstract: The Large Aperture Gamma Ray Burst Observatory (LAGO) is a project that aims to detect high energy photons from GRBs using the single particle technique in ground based Water Cherenkov Detectors (WCDs), which are able to detect most of the secondary particles produced by the interaction of these photons with atmospheric nuclei. To reach a reasonable sensitivity, high altitude mountain sites have been selected and detectors are deployed in eight different countries of Latin America. This work describes the initial testing and performance of a WCD prototype that has been implemented in Escuela Politécnica del Chimborazo in Riobamba, Ecuador, at 2784 m a.s.l. We use a commercial water tank (1100 l) and low cost accessories to build the detector, which will be later installed at 4800 m a.s.l. on the Chimborazo snowcap foothills. Data acquisition and post processing is done using the new electronic system designed for the LAGO detectors, which was developed by the LAGO Argentina team and is based on a digitizer board and a FPGA. This new hardware allows the storage of the time structure of all signals produced in the detector with 25 ns of time resolution. In addition, a water protocol procedure is described, which guarantees a stable performance of the WCD through time. Computer-aided simulations are being carried out during this year in order to calculate the theoretical efficiency of the WCD, properly calibrate the detector, and standardize the data with other LAGO WCD detectors. © 2013 Sociedade Brasileira de Fisica. All Rights Reserved.
Author Keywords: Gamma Ray Burst; LAGO Observatory; Water Cherenkov detectors
Index Keywords: Cerenkov counters; Cosmic rays; Cosmology; Costs; Data acquisition; Digital storage; Observatories; Photons; Stars; Water tanks; Commercial waters; Computer aided simulations; Electronic systems; Gamma ray bursts; High energy photons; Secondary particles; Theoretical efficiencies; Water Cherenkov detectors; Gamma rays

Title: Land degradation
Affiliations: Scientific Research Centre of the Slovenian Academy of Sciences and Arts, Anton Melik Geographical Institute, Novi trg 2, Ljubljana, 1000, Slovenia
Authors with affiliations: Zorn, M., Scientific Research Centre of the Slovenian Academy of Sciences and Arts, Anton Melik Geographical Institute, Novi trg 2, Ljubljana, 1000, Slovenia; Komac, B., Scientific Research Centre of the Slovenian Academy of Sciences and Arts, Anton Melik Geographical Institute, Novi trg 2, Ljubljana, 1000, Slovenia
Abstract: Land degradation is a natural or human-induced process that negatively affects the land. In general, it refers to the processes that negatively affect the land’s natural functions of water, energy, and nutrient acceptance, storage, and recycling, leading to a decline in land productivity. Humans are the major drivers of land degradation through socioeconomic and political pressures. Mechanisms that initiate land degradation include physical (decline in soil structure leading to crusting, compaction, hard-setting, erosion, natural disasters, desertification, anaerobism, environmental pollution, unsustainable use of natural resources, etc.), chemical (acidification, leaching, salinization, decrease in cation retention capacity, fertility depletion, etc.), and biological (reduction in total and biomass carbon, decline in land biodiversity, etc.) processes. © Springer Science+Business Media Dordrecht 2013.

Title: The role of the network planning process in upgrading network functionality to meet the requirements of independent power producers
Affiliations: AECOM, New Zealand
Authors with affiliations: Horvath, G.C., AECOM, New Zealand
Abstract: The relevance and the implications of Distributed Resources (DR) to the Network Services provided by network services providers is trying to undergo a revolution, which reflects the strong emphasis being placed on the uptake of DR within the energy policies of many countries. However, a bottleneck has formed through the inability of the energy networks to respond to the needs of DR at the volumes which would reflect the aspirations of the policy makers. This paper explores the idea that if the connection requirements of DR were integrated into the NSPs' planning processes then, more convenience and assurance could be achieved for DR proponents, thereby reducing the well-known non-price barriers to DR connection that has been a back-wind in realising the energy policies of many jurisdictions. The approach suggested in the paper, is to consider the accommodation by NSPs of the needs of DR, (whether it be wind resource, or PV, or a range of other resources such as intermittent storage), as a range of new Network Services that an NSP needs to provide at its points of interconnection with the grid. Then, through the normal Planning Process, and through the governance provided by the regulator, an NSP can work systematically, a) to define the levels of the new Network Services that it is able to provide at each POI; and b) to match the network capability to the expected demands for these Services that will manifest over the current planning cycle. Any shortfall can then be made good through the normal regulatory approval of CAPEX. Certainty is provided to prospective DR connectors through framing the new Network Services so as to be supportive and complying with their needs. However the expected impacts on the network of the forecast demand for DR connections, and therefore the new network services, are determined by the normal techniques of simulation utilised in a standard planning processes. © 2018 Israel Annual Conference on Aerospace Sciences. All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Distributed generation; Distributed resources; Network planning; Regulation of networks
Index Keywords: Distributed power generation; Energy policy; Wind power; Connection requirements; Distributed resources; Independent power producers; Network functionality; Network planning; Network planning process; Network services providers; Regulatory approvals; Electric utilities

Title: 2013 IEEE Energytech, Energytech 2013
Abstract: The proceedings contain 82 papers. The topics discussed include: WSN based heliostat control for a solar thermal cooking system; AlGaN/GaN HEMTs for energy efficient systems; agent based management of energy storage devices within a virtual energy storage; an advanced control method for saving energy in the tandem rolling of hot metal strip; agent-based control of a DC MicroGrid; a analytical study on electrochemistry for PKL (pathor kuchi leaf) electricity generation system; applicability of demand response to voltage control in a distribution system with large integration of rooftop PV; characterizing piezoelectric cantilevers for vibration energy harvesting under ambient conditions; automotive design challenges for wide-band-gap devices used in high temperature capable, scalable power vehicle electronics; commercialization of high 600V GaN-on-silicon power HEMTs and diodes; and community solutions initiative: IEEE power & energy society rural electrification initiative.

Title: 2013 Sustainable Internet and ICT for Sustainability, SustainIT 2013
Source title: 2013 Sustainable Internet and ICT for Sustainability, SustainIT 2013
Abstract: The proceedings contain 26 papers. The topics discussed include: effective consumption scheduling for demand-side management in the smart grid using non-uniform participation rate; an assessment of power-load proportionality in network systems; HFRBC-GA: a fuzzy classifier for energy systems applications; investigation into the energy cost of live migration of virtual machines; all electrical vehicles connected to the Internet: implementation and experiments; enhancing user privacy by preprocessing distributed smart meter data; user activity recognition for energy saving in smart homes; efficient demand assignment in multi-connected microgrids with a shared central grid; urban and social sensing for sustainable mobility in smart cities; a sensor-based power management system for sustainable computing in large environments; and building a network coded storage testbed for data center energy reduction.

Title: H2TRUST for hydrogen sustainability and safety
Abstract: Nine European partners, including associations, major companies, universities, technology and research centers from seven countries, have launched the H2TRUST consortium. The objective of the project is to foster a smooth and well managed transition to full-scale commercialization of fuel cell and hydrogen applications in Europe, and emphasize the importance of hydrogen safety among all stakeholders. Co-funded by the European Commission-supported Fuel Cells and Hydrogen Joint Undertaking, the H2TRUST consortium will run until November 2014. The project is led by Barcelona-based MATGAS, a joint venture between Air Products, the National Research Council of Spain, and the Autonomous University of Barcelona. The consortium members include Air Products, European Hydrogen Association, Solvay Speciality Polymers Italy, Politecnico di Milano, McPhy Energy in France, SOL SpA and CiaoTech (PNO Group) in Italy, and Eindhoven University of Technology in the Netherlands. One of the consortium's main goals is to evaluate industry efforts to ensure fuel cell and hydrogen technology remains safe, and that there is adequate regulation, hazard awareness, incident readiness, and ability to respond to any public concerns. Risk assessments will focus on each of the main application areas: hydrogen production, storage and distribution, mobility and vehicles, non-vehicles, and residential power generation.

Title: 11th International Conference on Synchrotron Radiation Instrumentation, SRI 2012 - High Energy Applications
Abstract: The proceedings contain 300 papers. The topics discussed include: the upgrade programme for the structural biology beam lines at the European synchrotron radiation facility - high throughput sample evaluation and automation; the preclinical set-up at the ID17 biomedical beamline to achieve high local dose deposition using interlaced microbeams; short period undulators for storage rings and free electron lasers; v-coupling-blades beam position monitor for NSRL undulator source; multilayer Laue lenses with focal length of 10 mm; timepix detector at the x-ray correlation spectroscopy instrument at LCLS; angle dispersive x-ray diffraction beamline on Indus-2 synchrotron radiation source: commissioning and first results; a two-dimensional event-counting detector for HV-CSA electrostatic analyzer at spline the Spanish CRG beamline at the ESRF; ultrafast laser pump x-ray probe experiments by means of asynchronous sampling; UHV superconducting magnet system for soft x-ray MCD experiments; and a high pressure XRD setup at ADXRD beamline (BL-12) on Indus-2.

Title: Modelling embedded technologies in energy service networks
Source title: Modelling Distributed Energy Resources in Energy Service Networks
Abstract: The chapter begins by explaining how to model a complex OLTC in electrical systems and then is followed by compressor unit modelling in gas systems. Subsequently, CHP and PHEV devices are portrayed, giving especial emphasis to the storage features they bring along to the integrated load flow problem. Laying a consistent framework for the representation of control mechanisms and distributed resources creates the opportunity to explore the operating trade-offs and interdependency relationships new technologies can have on energy service networks. © The Institution of Engineering and Technology 2013.
Author Keywords: CHP; Compressor unit modelling; Compressors; Energy service networks; Gas systems; Gas turbines; Integrated load flow; PHEV devices; Power transformers
Index Keywords: Compressors; Economic and social effects; Electric load flow; Gas compressors; Gas turbines; Power transformers; Compressor units; Energy services; Gas systems; Load flow; PHEV devices; Compressibility of gases

Title: Preface: International workshop on solar chemical energy storage
Authors with affiliations: Nakano, Y.; Sugiyama, M.
Abstract: [No abstract available]

Title: AIP Conference Proceedings
Abstract: The proceedings contain 20 papers. The topics discussed include: solar fuels production by artificial photosynthesis; new materials for photocatalytic and photoelectrochemical water splitting; selective co2 reduction conjugated with H2O oxidation utilizing semiconductor/metal-complex hybrid photocatalysts; perspective view of GSC: how to realize the industrial application of artificial photo synthesis?; heteroepitaxial III-V on Si(100) tandem absorbers structures for photoelectrolysis; basic study for the application of Cu supported ZnS and ZnO photocatalysts for the CO2 conversion into alcohol; capacitance measurements for AlGaN/GaN photoelectrochemical electrode by using electrolyte contact and by metal contact; structural basis of photosynthetic water-splitting; water oxidation reaction in natural and artificial photosynthetic systems; rational design of semiconductors for photoelectrochemical water splitting; time-dependent first-principles approaches to pv materials; microscopic understanding of the electrochemical interfaces; on the thermodynamic stability of hydrogen hydrates in the presence of promoter molecules; a study of QM/Langevin-MD simulation for oxygen-evolving center of photosystem II; theoretical investigation on single-molecule chiroptical spectroscopy; effective hydrogen generation and resource circulation based on sulfur cycle system; basic study for the construction of solar cell using CdS photocatalysts and Na2S4 electrolyte; and simulation-based design of energy management system with storage battery for a refugee shelter in Japan.

Title: International Workshop on Practical Applications of Agents and Multi-Agent Systems, PAAMS 2013
Source title: Communications in Computer and Information Science
Abstract: The proceedings contain 43 papers. The special focus in this conference is on Workshop on Agent-Based Approaches for the Transportation Modeling and Optimization, Workshop on Agent-Based Solutions for Manufacturing and Supply Chain, Workshop on Conflict Resolution in Decision Making and Workshop on Multi-Agent System Based Learning Environments. The topics include: Social control of power system demand based on local collaborative preferences; agent-driven variable pricing in flexible rural transport services; a norm-based probabilistic decision-making model for autonomic traffic networks; reactive coordination rules for traffic optimization in road sharing problems; multimodal processes cyclic steady states scheduling; situated MAS approach for freight trains assembly; simultaneous scheduling of machines and mobile robots; characterization of the radio propagation channel in a real scenario; dynamic propagation analysis in urban environments; comparing agent interactions of distributed and centralized multi-agent systems for context-aware domains; indoor augmented reality based on ultrasound localization systems; dynamic signature verification on smart phones; a self-configurable agent-based system for intelligent storage in smart grid; strategies for cooperation emergence in distributed service discovery; a negotiation approach for energy-aware room allocation systems; an intelligent tutoring systems integrated with learning management systems; a semantic web approach to recommend learning objects; an agent-based middleware for cooperating smart objects; simulating the impacts of the energy consumption using multi-agent systems; user-centered ubiquitous multi-agent model for e-health web-based recommender applications development and requirements for an intelligent ambient assisted living application for Parkinson patients.

Title: 3rd International Conference on Cloud Computing, CloudComp 2012
Source title: Lecture Notes of the Institute for Computer Sciences, Social-Informatics and Telecommunications Engineering, LNICST
Abstract: The proceedings contain 14 papers. The special focus in this conference is on Cloud Computing. The topics include: A conceptual framework for simulating autonomic cloud markets; opinion model based security reputation enabling cloud broker architecture; cloud security and privacy in the light of the 2012 EU data protection regulation; biometric identity trust: toward secure biometric enrollment in web environments; future of cloud-based services for multi-factor authentication: results of a delphi study; assessing the readiness to move into the cloud; design and implementation of a multi-objective optimization mechanism for virtual machine placement in cloud computing data center; agent based application tools for cloud provisioning and management; performance evaluation of embedded processor in mapreduce cloud computing applications; power-aware autonomous distributed storage systems for internet hosting service platforms; a digital infrastructure for green utility computing: the preliminary holistic research agenda; energy-aware multi-agent server consolidation in federated clouds and specifying cloud application requirements: an ontological approach.

Title: 7th International Conference on River Basin Management, RBM 2013
Source title: WIT Transactions on Ecology and the Environment
Abstract: The proceedings contain 37 papers. The special focus in this conference is on Hydrological Modelling, Hydrodynamics, Flood Risk Management, Water Resources Management, Erosion and Sediment Transport, Erosion and Sediment Transport, River Restoration and Rehabilitation, Changing Climate and Water Quality. The topics include: Precipitation thresholds for drought recognition: a further use of the standardized precipitation index, SPI; on the coupling of water cycle components; a new synthetic unit hydrograph computation method based on the mass conservation principle; flood modelling of upper gurara watershed using remote sensing data and the geospatial streamflow model; flow modelling of dual permeability systems: the case of the Vigolana Massif (Trento, Northern Italy); the role of slope on the overland flow production; friction factor of a meandering open channel flow; energy and momentum coefficients for wide compound channels; distribution of boundary shear in compound channel with rough floodplains; facing global water problems; the application of artificial e intelligence for monthly rainfall forecasting in the Brisbane Catchment, Queensland, Australia; ethiopian planned water projects on the Juba and Shabelle rivers and effects on downstream uses in Somalia; managing conflicts in water resources allocation; evaluation of surface water storage; rainwater harvesting experiences of the CIDECALLI and CFE; an assessment of the rate of siltation in Jibia reservoir, Jibia, Katsina state; evaluation of metals in water and sediments of micro-basins in the city of Americana, Sao Paulo state, Brazil; sediment and nutrient behaviour on the River Bandon, Ireland; comparison of clear water flow and sediment flow through bottom racks using some lab measurements and CFD methodology; effect of a subsidiary pillar on local scour at a bridge pier; prediction formulas of maximum scour depth and impact location of a local scour hole below a chute spillway with a flip bucket; influence of submerged groynes for urban creek rehabilitation on aquatic environment at Sawmill Creek in Ottawa, Canada; bank erosion and planimetric evolution of alluvial meandering streams; river bank erosion risk potential with regards to soil erodibility; integrating flood mitigation, sediment management and habitat enhancement on coastal rivers of British Columbia; re-oligotrophication of tropical water reservoirs to minimize environmental impact; a study of the diversity of natural topography in straight and meandering streams by the installation of groynes; deconstructing the native fish strategy for Australia's Murray Darling catchment; soil bio-engineering experiences in river works using wire mesh products; comparison of precipitation trends in Libya and Slovakia; assessing ecological response of the big pine creek watershed to climate change using time series analysis of landsat surface reflectance data over a 28-year period; trends in hydro-climatic variables and dissolved oxygen of the river Periyar, South India with potential impacts of global warming; sustainable solutions for cost effective rainwater harvesting in Nepal; online water quality monitoring: a network to support water management in the Erft river basin; water quality modelling in tidal wetlands considering flooding and drying processes; identification of organic compounds in the bottom sediments of Moscow urban rivers and initial improvement of a sewage system after embankment: a combined index of water and sediment quality.
